div.p:
My Father has begun a negotiation respecting the greyhounds the issue of which I shall know before I finish this letter & will then tell you the particulars -- I am so sorry that they should inconvenience you -- So sorry that we should not ourselves have room for them -- So sorry that just now when you have so well earned every sort of pleasure, one so simple & so fine should be taken from you. These regrets are very useless -- but one cannot help feeling them. ---- Do not commit such a mistake & so fancy your hand writing illegible -- I can read it as well as print -- The characters are peculiar but the moment one knows them by heart one reads them as easily as a scholar reads Greek. Oh my dear Mr. Haydon if only you were but to see some of the young-lady correspondences which
befall one sometimes - a full sheet of foolscap twice crossed in a hand all Ms & Ns -- a series of ups & downs which defy guessing -- I was forced to turn off a cousin of my own a delightful woman whose letters had but one fault that of being wholly unintelligible from beginning to end -- nothing could be prettier looking than her hand only it was utterly unreadable. Never think of calling that writing of yours which shews so plainly the repricocity & energy of your spirit, a scrawl -- with what a delightful hieroglyphic you eked it out in your stage Iago! I have seen Kean both in Othello & Iago, & I felt like you his terrible power in the former. To see Kean in Othello is a very painful pleasure. If I may say it without danger of being suspected of affectation I must confess that I do not much like acted plays. Kean is disappointing & unequal -- & Kemble was cold -- & one loses all the sweetness & poetry of those delicious plays in these great theatres where nothing but the coarser strokes fell -- In short it is altogether owing to my intense love & admiration of for Shakespeare & the old Dramatists that
I never desire to see a favorite play acted. Did you ever read two plays by Thomas May the Historian of the Long Parliament which I wonder Mr. Harbilt did not mention -- The Heir & The Old Couple? They are as sweet & beautiful as a May morning. ---- All in a little O
Sir William Elford Do you read the Scotch novels Have you read the Abbot? Do you like it? I was disappointed beccause every alternate work has been excellent & as the Monastery was bad I expected this to be very good -- after all it is ungrateful to impute as a fault the failure of one's own too high expectation -- It is very pleasant reading through not a work that would have made a reputation like Waverly or Old Mortality. The real fault lies in the subject. Mary Queen of Scots is a person of whom in spite of her sins we have dreamt all our life long. There is not a man of any imagination who has not made her romance in his own mind long before now -- The Bodleian Mary full of beauty & grace - the love of men the envy of women - She who makes possible all that has been feigned of nymph of Goddess then
is no writing up to what one fancies of her. --Schiller has tried & Alfieri & both have failed -- but though Sir Walter Scott's failure the most egregious of any - He takes the Venus down from her pedenstal & makes her scold -- he disenchants the Lady Dulcinea -- he lets the glaring daylight into the magic lantern & puts out the dreamy pictures -- now this is not a friend's office - nor a poet's - This is another fault too -- All the plot that is not of Queen Mary is filled by a twin brother & sister confusion, like that of Viola & Sebastian in Twelfth Night -- & let the Edinburgh reviewers say what they will Walter Scott at the side of Shakespeare cuts no better a figure than Reynolds by the side of Vandyke. Nevertheless the book is pleasant and free from his peculiar faults and from his stinking beauties -- only one old hag -- no fortune scene - no prophecy & no ghost. How sorry I am to hear so bad an account of Mr. Keats --When I write to Miss James I will mention your kind permission to send me his book.
